user_request: A Father's Day poem about a dad being a hero and role model.

revision_history.draft:
His breath on the kitchen window
leaves a message no one reads.

I hear it first — the lawn mower,
that thin guttural thing that cuts
through someone else's yard like a blade
through something he can stand to keep.

Before the coffee heats up,
before the Bible opens itself
to whatever page it chooses,
he sits with his shoes off, socks drawn
up past ankles that have forgotten
what dry land feels like,

and I watch his hand unfold
a newspaper no one folds anymore,
the way he cradles it as if wrapping
something fragile enough to be
someone's idea of morning.

The dog has been barking since three.
Some hare or fox on the property line
he'll never see, and he waits out it too,
patient as the pilot light
on the coffee maker, which has memorized
the smell of being almost alive.

I have not woken. The linoleum
holds its cold like a kind of discipline —
how you have to earn the room back,
folding sheets or pouring milk
into cereal with the left hand only,
naming each bowl after someone slept through it.

His fingers find the keychain
without looking. Three rings of nothing.
The coffee is getting warm now,
which means soon someone will drink from it,
and I think about how objects
have more attention than we do —
how they hold their single thing
the way a person holds a secret
they can't explain and doesn't want to.

He shifts the key to his thumb.
It clicks against the tile. He clicks it back.
This is what heroes do at five a.m.:
they keep the keys, they start the engine,
they let the yard speak for them.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The poem has genuine structural intelligence. The domestic accumulation — coffee pilot light, dog barking at three, linoleum cold as discipline, the keychain click — builds a world that feels inhabited rather than decorated. The final image of him clicking the keychain: that is the poem's real subject. Everything else orbits it.

The line "how they hold their single thing / the way a person holds a secret" risks abstraction but earns its place because it arrives after the concrete images of left-handed cereal pouring and naming bowls after absent sleepers. The poem knows what it wants to say by that point, so the summary is allowed.

The enjambment is working hard — "cuts through something he can stand to keep" breaks across a line with genuine tension. "Folds each bowl after someone slept through it" earns its length because "bowl" does double duty (container and thing named for another person). These are specific choices, not decorative ones.

The dog barking at nothing gets the poem's attention — that's real perception, not stock imagery.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / editorializing — lines 17–20:**
> I have not woken. The linoleum
> holds its cold like a kind of discipline —
> how you have to earn the room back,
> folding sheets or pouring milk
> into cereal with the left hand only,
> naming each bowl after someone slept through it.
>
> His fingers find the keychain
> without looking. Three rings of nothing.

The passage from "I have not woken" through "slept through it" is the poem explaining itself to the reader instead of letting the images do that work. "Folding sheets or pouring milk / into cereal with the left hand only, / naming each bowl after someone slept through it" — this is a list of things that could all appear in one image without editorial comment. The "how you have to earn the room back" line breaks the immersion for no payoff.

**Direction:** Cut or radically compress lines 17–20. Let the images of pouring left-handed, naming bowls after absent people, and the keychain click stand as a single sequence. Trust the accumulation. If the poem needs one more image to arrive at its subject (the clicking), that's fine — but "earning the room back" is the poet narrating what should be visible.

**Cliché — line 10:**
> and I watch his hand unfold
> a newspaper no one folds anymore,

This reads like a cliché of the pandemic era. It gestures at something without landing on anything particular. Is it actually *no one* or is it specific? The vagueness kills it.

**Direction:** Make this concrete — what does he do with the paper beyond unfolding? What's in his hands while

revision_history.draft:
His breath on the kitchen window
leaves a message no one reads.

I hear it first — the lawn mower,
that thin guttural thing that cuts
through someone else's yard like a blade
through something he can stand to keep.

Before the coffee, before script,
he sits with shoes off, socks drawn
past ankles forgotten. His hand

finds the paper flat as any skin,
curls it toward the fold worn loose—
a wrinkle he repairs the way
you'd press a crease into a friend's jacket,
careful, almost embarrassed.

The dog has been at it since three.
Some hare or fox on the property line
he'll never see. He waits out the bark
the way the pilot light waits
on the coffee maker, memorizing
the smell of being almost alive.

His fingers find the keychain—
three rings of nothing—and he clicks
the key to his thumb, then clicks it back,
then clicks it again the way
a hero starts a engine at five a.m.:
they let the yard speak for them.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The final sequence is the strongest work in this revision:

> His fingers find the keychain — three rings of nothing.
> The coffee is getting warm now,
> which means soon someone will drink from it.

This earns its place because everything preceding it has built the domestic world with enough precision that "someone will drink" lands as revelation. The click-to-thumb-click repetition, the worn keychain, the warmth — these are concrete and trusted.

The dog barking at three AM is alive: "Some hare or fox on the property line / he'll never see." That "never see" does real perceptual work — it's precise in what it denies. The lawn mower line

> that thin guttural thing that cuts
> through someone else's yard like a blade
> through something he can stand to keep.

Still has some editorializing ("guttural," "thin") that could be cut or replaced with a more specific sensory detail — the actual sound, not the feeling about the sound. The keychain click is the poem's subject arriving at last.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / editorializing — lines 17–20 (cut entirely):**

> I have not woken. The linoleum
> holds its cold like a kind of discipline —
> how you have to earn the room back,
> folding sheets or pouring milk
> into cereal with the left hand only,
> naming each bowl after someone slept through it.
>
> His fingers find the keychain
> without looking. Three rings of nothing.

These lines narrate what the images should be doing. Cut them entirely. The poem's subject — a man starting at five who lets you sleep — arrives in "His fingers find." That line is already the summary, and it works better as action than as explanation.

**Cliché / vagueness — line 10:**

> and I watch his hand unfold
> a newspaper no one folds anymore,

"Unfolds," "no one folds anymore" — this reads like a greeting-card shorthand. The poem is stronger when it stays in the man's hands:

> His fingers find the keychain — three rings of nothing.
> A wrinkle he repairs the way
> you'd press a crease into a friend's jacket,
> careful, almost embarrassed.

That's more specific and earned. Trust the domestic gesture over the abstraction.

**Weak line break — line 15:**

> The dog has been at it since three.
> Some hare or fox on the property line
> he'll never see.

"Has been at it" is filler before "some hare." Cut "it" — the poem doesn't need it, and the line stalls. Make "Some hare or fox on the property line" land as its own unit.

**Direction:** The revision is

final_poem:
His breath on the kitchen window
leaves a message no one reads.

I hear it first — the lawn mower,
that thin guttural thing that cuts
through someone else's yard like a blade
through something he can stand to keep.

Before coffee, before script,
he sits with shoes off, socks drawn
past ankles forgotten. His hand

finds the paper flat as skin,
curls it toward the fold worn loose—
a wrinkle he repairs the way
you'd press a crease into a friend's jacket,
careful, almost embarrassed.

The dog has been at it since three.
Some hare or fox on the property line
he'll never see. He waits out the bark
the way the pilot light waits
on the coffee maker: memorizing
the smell of being almost alive.

His fingers find the keychain—
three rings of nothing—and he clicks
the key to his thumb, then clicks it back,
then clicks it again the way
a hero starts an engine at five a.m.:
they let the yard speak for them.

He folds the paper into shape.
The cup warms on the counter—
stronger every morning like a body
learning what it can stand.
